questions.text: A 74-year-old man was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder. Which of the following is the most likely risk factor for this type of bladder cancer?
questions.explanation:
Histologic Type of Bladder Carcinoma

Risk Factors

Transitional cell carcinoma (>97%)
  • Smoking
  • Occupational exposure (aromatic hydrocarbons):
    • Rubber, paint and dyes, gas and tar industries
    • Hairdressers, plumbers, and painters (Option C)
  • Environmental carcinogens: Arsenic in drinking water
  • Schistosomiasis (SCC >> transitional cell Ca)
  • Drugs: Phenacetin, Cyclophosphamide (Option D)
  • Pelvic radiotherapy

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (1-7%)
  • Schistosomiasis (Option A)
  • Secondary to chronic infections:
  • Indwelling catheter
  • Bladder stone
  • Recurrent infections

Adenocarcinoma (2%)
  • Urachus
  • Augmentation enterocystoplasty
  • Bladder exstrophy repair (Option B)

Rare (<1%): Melanoma, lymphoma, sarcoma, small cell carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, metastatic adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A patient who had undergone cystectomy and urinary diversion with an ileal conduit after being diagnosed with muscle-invasive bladder cancer comes for follow-up. His blood investigations revealed an electrolyte imbalance. Which of the following is not a possible imbalance in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ileum vs. Colon Absorption
  • Ileum: Absorbs less chloride, more potassium
  • Colon: Absorbs more chloride, less potassium.

Electrolyte Imbalances in Metabolic Acidosis
  • Hypokalemia (Option A): Low potassium levels due to intestinal losses and renal wasting.
  • Hypocalcemia (Option C): Low calcium levels due to renal wasting and bone demineralization.
  • Hypomagnesemia (Option D): Low magnesium levels due to renal wasting.

Hyperchloremic Acidosis Mechanism
  • Ammonium Ion Dissociation: Ammonium (NH4+) dissociates into ammonia (NH3) and hydrogen ions (H+).
  • Ammonia Handling: Ammonia enters cells, and hydrogen ions are actively absorbed in exchange for sodium
  • Ammonium Absorption: Ammonium can enter cells via potassium channels, substituting potassium.
  • Chloride Absorption: Balanced by the absorption of chloride, leading to hyperchloremic acidosis and bicarbonate loss.

Hypocalcemia Mechanism
  • Bone Buffering: Chronic metabolic acidosis is buffered by bone carbonate, releasing calcium from bones.
  • Bone Demineralization: Calcium released from bone is not reabsorbed, leading to decreased body calcium stores.
  • Renal Wasting: Increased renal loss of calcium contributes to hypocalcemia.

Effects of Urinary Diversion
  • Chronic metabolic acidosis following urinary diversion leads to continuous buffering by bone carbonate, causing bone demineralization.

questions.text: A new mother comes to the outpatient department with her neonate as she notices intermittent fluid leaking from the umbilicus of the baby. On examination, the umbilicus is inflamed, enlarged, and there is delayed healing of the cord stump. What is the diagnosis?
A 55-year-old male with non-muscle invasive bladder carcinoma is advised TURBT and BCG immunotherapy due to a high risk of recurrence. Which condition is not a contraindication for BCG therapy?
questions.explanation:
Administration

  • Intravesical instillations: Administered postoperatively
  • Induction therapy: Weekly for 6 weeks
  • Maintenance therapy: Every 3 weeks for 3 years (variable intervals for 1-3 years)

Timing
  • BCG Therapy: Administered 6 weeks post-operatively, not immediately. (Option B)
  • Mitomycin C: Given immediately post-operatively.

Agents

  • BCG (Bacillus Calmette-Guérin): Live attenuated vaccine.
  • Mitomycin C: Antineoplastic agent.

Mechanism of Action
  • BCG Therapy: Elicits a massive influx of inflammatory cells and cytokines, inducing an inflammatory response against neoplastic cells.

Side Effects
  • Transient fever
  • Frequency
  • Dysuria
  • Urgency
  • BCG Cystitis
  • BCG Sepsis

Contraindications
  • Immunocompromised Patients: (Option A) Risk of BCG sepsis; requires a competent immune system.
  • Gross Hematuria: Risk of BCG entering circulation and causing systemic infection.
  • Total Urinary Incontinence (Option C): BCG is ineffective if it cannot remain in the bladder.
  • History of Previous BCG Sepsis or Hypersensitivity: Risk of severe reactions.

Other Systemic Chemotherapy Agents Used
  • Cisplatin or gemcitabine and cisplatin.
  • Methotrexate
  • Vinblastine
  • Doxorubicin (Adriamycin)

Intravesical antineoplastic agent
  • Mitomycin C

questions.text: During a radical cystectomy for bladder cancer in males, which of the following structures is typically spared and not removed?
questions.explanation:
Structures Removed During Radical Cystectomy

Indications for Radical Cystectomy

Indications for Partial Cystectomy
  • Entire Bladder
  • Prostate (Males)
  • Seminal Vesicles (Males)
  • Urethra
  • Regional Lymph Nodes
  • Uterus and Ovaries (Females)
  • Invasive Bladder Cancer: Spread beyond the bladder lining
  • Non-Muscle Invasive Bladder Cancer: Recurrent and unresponsive to other treatments
  • Single Tumor: Confined to a single area of the bladder
  • Limited to Bladder Wall: Does not involve surrounding tissues or organs
  • Persistent or recurrent tumors in a localized area
  • High-Grade Tumors: Confined to a specific area, does not involve deeper layers or distant sites
  • Preservation of Bladder Function

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred initial therapy for a patient with carcinoma in situ (Tis) urinary bladder cancer after TURBT?
questions.explanation:
Tumor Stage

Tis (Carcinoma in situ)

TURBT (Transurethral Resection of Bladder Tumor)

  • May be used for initial diagnosis and tumor resection if not already performed

Intravesical BCG

  • Induction: Weekly for 6 weeks
  • Maintenance: Weekly for 3 weeks at months 3, 6, 12, 18, 24, 30, and 36

Continue BCG Maintenance Therapy

  • Up to 3 years

Ta (Non-muscle invasive)

TURBT

  • Complete resection of tumor

Low-risk:

  • Single Instillation (SI) of Intravesical Chemotherapy (e.g., gemcitabine, mitomycin)
  • SI within 24 hours of TURBT
  • Alternative: Continuous saline bladder irrigation

Intermediate-risk:

  • Intravesical Chemotherapy (e.g., gemcitabine)
  • Induction: 6 weekly courses
  • Maintenance: Up to 1 year

T1 (Muscle invasive)

TURBT- For initial diagnosis and tumor debulking

High-risk:

  • Intravesical BCG
  • Induction: Weekly for 6 weeks
  • Maintenance: Up to 3 years

Consider Cystectomy

  • If BCG is not tolerated or ineffective- Alternative: Trimodality therapy (TURBT + Chemoradiation)

T2 (Muscle invasive)

TURBT- May be used for tumor resection and staging

Initial Treatment:

  • Consider Cystectomy
  • Alternatively, Trimodality therapy (TURBT + Chemoradiation)

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • Depending on response and tumor characteristics

T3 (Advanced muscle invasive)

Initial Treatment:

  • Cystectomy with possible neoadjuvant chemotherapy

TURBT - Often not performed if cystectomy is planned

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • Based on pathology and staging
  • Neoadjuvant therapy may continue

T4 (Locally advanced)

Initial Treatment:

  • Cystectomy
  • Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy, if not yet administered

TURBT- Typically avoided if cystectomy and neoadjuvant therapy are planned

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • Additional chemotherapy or radiation based on residual disease and staging

questions.text: Which of the following is not a tumor marker for urinary bladder cancer?
questions.explanation:
Investigations for urinary bladder cancer

Cystoscopy

Gold standard for bladder cancer diagnosis and staging; suspicious lesions should be biopsied or resected.

Urine Cytology

Used as an adjunct to cystoscopy.

To confirm the diagnosis - has high specificity but low sensitivity.

Detects high-grade urothelial carcinoma by identifying exfoliated cancer cells.

Fluorescence Cystoscopy

Enhances the detection of tumors but may have a higher false-positive rate.

Urinary Tract Imaging

CT scan is preferred for all stages; IVP is an alternative if CT is not available but is less commonly used.

Tumor Markers

Helpful in diagnosis and for follow-up to assist the response of therapy and to detect recurrence

NMP22 (Nuclear Matrix Protein 22)

(Option B)

Measures levels of a protein released from bladder cancer cells into the urine.

BTA (Bladder Tumor Antigen)

(Option C)

Detects proteins associated with bladder cancer in the urine.

Lewis X antigen

Immunocytological detection of the Lewis X antigen on exfoliated bladder cells has improved the identification of urothelial tumor cells.

Hyaluronidase

(Option A)

Elevated levels of urinary HA and HAase have been observed in patients with bladder cancer.

HYAL-1 hyaluronidase is a potential prognostic marker for predicting muscle invasion and recurrence in non-muscle-invasive bladder cancer.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a bladder tumor invading the muscle layer is classified as which TNM stage?
questions.explanation:
Primary Tumor Staging (TNM System)

The depth of invasion of the primary tumor in bladder cancer is a crucial prognostic factor for recurrence and progression.

Ta Lesions

(Option A)

Papillary (exophytic) tumors with a tendency to recur.

Tis Lesions

High-grade intraepithelial neoplasms (carcinoma in situ [CIS]) without invasion into subepithelial connective tissue.

T1 Lesions

(Option B)

Tumors invade the submucosa or lamina propria, typically high-grade.

T2 Lesions

(Option C)

Tumors invade muscle; cystectomy is standard therapy.

Presence of muscle invasion increases the likelihood of nodal and distant metastases.

T3 Lesions

(Option D)

Tumors extend beyond muscle into perivesical fat. Imaging (CT, MRI, PET) may help identify disease spread outside the bladder.

T4 Lesions

Tumors extend into adjacent organs.

T4a - invasion into the prostate, vagina, uterus, or bowel

T4b - tumors fixed to the abdominal wall, pelvic wall, or other organs.

Regional Lymph Nodes & Distant Metastases

Description

N1

Involvement of a single lymph node within the true pelvis.

N2

Involvement of multiple lymph nodes within the true pelvis.

N3

Spread to the common iliac lymph nodes.

M1a

Lymph node involvement beyond the common iliac lymph nodes.

M1b

Involvement of distant organs (non-lymph node distant metastases).

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with muscle-invasive bladder cancer is undergoing evaluation for metastasis. What is the most common lymphatic node involved in bladder cancer metastasis?
questions.explanation:
Route of metastasis:
  • Direct extension into adjacent organs and/or the pelvic sidewall
  • Lymphatic spread
  • Hematogenous spread

Sites of Metastasis:
  • Lymph Nodes (69%): Pelvic (m/c) > Retroperitoneal > Intrathoracic > Supraclavicular Nodes
  • Bone (47%): Lytic lesions, sclerotic lesions or mixed lesions
  • Lungs (37%): Pulmonary nodules or consolidations
  • Liver (26%): Multiple Lesions or Solitary Lesions
  • Peritoneum (16%)
  • Other Metastatic Sites: Soft tissue, adrenal glands, brain
  • Tumors in a more advanced T category and those with atypical histologic features metastasize earlier.
  • Tumors with atypical histologic features also have a higher frequency of peritoneal metastasis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of smoking presents with frequent urination and microscopic hematuria. Cystoscopy reveals a flat, high-grade lesion confined to the bladder epithelium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Papillary tumors

Carcinoma in situ (CIS)
  • A condition in which abnormal cells are found in the tissue lining the inside of the bladder, renal pelvis, or ureter.
  • Also called stage 0a bladder cancer or stage 0a transitional cell cancer (Ta, N0, M0).
  • Originate from papillary urothelial hyperplasia.
  • Long, thin, finger-like growths under microscope. (Option A)
  • Can be low or high grade.
  • May become cancer and spread to nearby normal tissue.
  • Epithelial lesions that have cytologic features of malignancy but are confined to the epithelium, with no basement membrane invasion.
  • Also called stage Tis bladder cancer or stage Tis transitional cell cancer (Tis, N0, M0).
  • High-grade, flat tumor on the bladder's inner lining, not invading deeper tissues.
  • Symptoms:
    • Dysuria
    • Nocturia
    • Frequent and urgent urination
    • Microscopic hematuria (Option B)
  • Diagnosis: Urine cytology, histopathology, immunostaining (CK 20, p53, CD44), and FISH for chromosome abnormalities.
  • Treatment: Intravesical BCG preferred

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) is brought with a few episodes of hematuria and bladder discomfort. Imaging shows a diverticulum near the ureteric orifice. Which of the following statements is most accurate based on the clinical scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: Congenital diverticulum due to its location and UTIs.

options.label: B
options.text: Occurs secondary to high intravesical pressure.

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate surgery is needed regardless of symptoms.

questions.correct_answer: A. Congenital diverticulum due to its location and UTIs.
questions.explanation:
Type

Congenital Diverticula

Acquired Diverticula

Cause

Develops due to herniation of bladder mucosa through congenital muscular defect between the intravesical ureter and roof of ureteral hiatus called Hutch diverticulum.

Secondary to bladder outlet obstruction, often due to prostatic issues in adult men.

Bladder characteristics

Thin-walled, typically located near the ureteric orifice, associated with vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) (Option A)
  • Thick-walled with trabeculations and multiple diverticula. (Option D)
  • High intravesical pressure causes bladder mucosa to protrude, forming saccules, which can become diverticula. (Option B)

Symptoms or complications

 
  • Haematuria (due to infection, stone or tumor) (30%)
  • Recurrent UTIs
  • Bladder stones
  • Urinary retention
  • Hydronephrosis
  • Bladder tumors (1%)

Diagnosis

  • Imaging (ultrasound, CT, MRI, cystogram) or cystoscopy.
  • Confirm bladder outlet obstruction with urodynamics if suspected.

Bladder diverticulum MRI:

Bladder diverticulum CT:

Cystogram with bladder diverticulum:

Cystoscopical view of bladder diverticulum:

Treatment

  • Congenital bladder diverticula is treated if symptomatic or for suspected malignancy. (Option C)
  • Open surgery or minimally invasive techniques for excision of diverticula; May require ureteric reimplantation based on diverticulum location.
  • Repair is done extravesical or through a combined extravesical or intravesical approach.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with severe abdominal pain and inability to urinate after a car accident. On examination, he has diffuse abdominal tenderness with guarding and rigidity. A cystogram reveals urine leakage into the peritoneal cavity. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Grade

Injury

Description

I

Haematoma

Contusion, intramural haematoma

Laceration

Partial thickness

II

Laceration

Extraperitoneal bladder wall laceration <2 cm

III

Laceration

Extraperitoneal ≥2 cm or intraperitoneal <2 cm bladder wall laceration

IV

Laceration

Intraperitoneal bladder wall laceration ≥2 cm

V

Laceration

Laceration extending into the bladder neck or ureteral orifice (trigone)

questions.text: A 48-year-old female presents with chronic pelvic pain, urinary urgency, and frequency. On cystoscopy, a characteristic bladder lesion with a small capacity and visible mucosal breaks is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: C. Interstitial Cystitis with Hunner’s Lesion
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Cystoscopic Findings

Hunner’s lesions (ulcerative lesions), small bladder capacity, and mucosal breaks

Symptoms

Chronic pelvic pain, urinary urgency, frequency, nocturia

Etiology

Uncertain, though associated with autoimmune, neurogenic, and allergic etiologies

Differential Diagnosis

Bladder cancer, UTI, Radiation cystitis, Endometriosis

Treatment
  • Behavioral therapy
  • Pharmacotherapy (e.g., pentosan polysulfate sodium)
  • Intravesical therapies (e.g., GAG layer replacement therapies, dimethyl sulfoxide)
  • Surgical interventions (e.g., Fulguration or laser therapy for Hunner lesions, cystectomy in severe cases)

questions.text: Based on the images provided, where would each of the shown catheters be used? Image 1: Image 2:

options.label: A
options.text: Image 1:Used for patients with acute urinary retention; Image 2:Used only in neurogenic bladder

options.label: B
options.text: Image 1: Used for patients with an enlarged prostate causing retention; Image 2: Used in cases of urethral stricture or trauma

options.label: C
options.text: Image 1: Used for short-term postoperative bladder drainage; Image 2:Used only when Foley's catheterization is contraindicated

options.label: D
options.text: Image 1: Used for patients with acute urinary retention; Image 2:Used for continuous bladder irrigation

questions.correct_answer: B. Image 1: Used for patients with an enlarged prostate causing retention; Image 2: Used in cases of urethral stricture or trauma
questions.explanation:
Urinary catheters

General Information on Catheters

Therapeutic Uses: Drug delivery, drainage, diagnostics.

Classification: Size, composition (silicone or latex-coated), number of channels.

Measurement: French scale, where 1 French (Fr) = 0.3 mm in diameter.

The standard sizes are:

  • Women: 12Fr or 14Fr & Men: 16Fr
  • Smaller sizes are used for urethral stricture.
  • 22Fr catheters are used for hematuria with clot retention.

Suprapubic Catheterization

Suprapubic catheterization (SPC) is the insertion of a catheter into the bladder through the abdominal wall above the pubic bone.

Types of Urethral Catheters

Single-Channel Catheters: One drainage channel, used for clean intermittent self-catheterization, no indwelling retention mechanism.

Two-Channel Catheters: Drainage channel + balloon inflation channel, standard for uncomplicated urinary retention.

Three-way Catheters: Additional channel for bladder irrigation, used for clot retention, hematuria, post-bladder or transurethral prostate surgery.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident with a pelvic fracture and gross hematuria. The CT cystogram showed the following characteristic findings. Which of the following statements regarding the diagnosis of this patient is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Retrograde cystography demonstrates extravasation of contrast limited to the perivesical space.

options.label: B
options.text: Catheter drainage for 10-14 days is the treatment of choice for uncomplicated cases.

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate surgical repair in cases of bladder neck injury.

options.label: D
options.text: Both urethral and suprapubic catheters are recommended in all cases.

questions.correct_answer: D. Both urethral and suprapubic catheters are recommended in all cases.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with recurrent UTIs and a history of chronic immunosuppression after a renal transplant presents with non-tender abdominal nodules. The biopsy shows histiocytes with basophilic inclusions staining positive for PAS and von Kossa stains. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Commonly associated with Gram-negative bacteria like E. coli

options.label: B
options.text: Characteristic histological feature is Langhans giant cells

options.label: D
options.text: Usually self-limiting and resolves without treatment

questions.correct_answer: A. Commonly associated with Gram-negative bacteria like E. coli
questions.explanation:
Malakoplakia

Common Pathogen

Escherichia coli (most common), other Gram-negative bacteria

Histopathology

Von Hansemann cells (foamy histiocytes) with Michaelis-Gutmann bodies (PAS-positive inclusions)

Characteristic Inclusions

Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, which are basophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions

Staining

Positive staining with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS), von Kossa, and Perl’s stains

Associated Conditions

Immunocompromised states, such as organ transplantation, HIV, diabetes, malignancy

Organ Involvement

Predominantly genitourinary tract, but can affect multiple organ systems

Treatment

Antibiotics (fluoroquinolones, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole), possible surgical excision

Prognosis

Requires treatment; may lead to complications if untreated; variable course with potential relapses

questions.text: A 45-year-old male tourist from rural Egypt presents with recurrent hematuria and lower abdominal pain. A pelvic radiograph shows a circular calcification resembling a fetal head in the pelvis with associated faint calcification of the distal right ureter. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate next step?

options.label: B
options.text: Chronic schistosomiasis; obtain urine microscopy for ova

options.label: C
options.text: Pelvic tuberculosis; order interferon-gamma release assay

options.label: D
options.text: Calcified bladder tumor; schedule CT urography

questions.correct_answer: B. Chronic schistosomiasis; obtain urine microscopy for ova
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Endemic regions

Africa, Middle-East (especially Egypt)

Clinical presentation

Recurrent hematuria, lower abdominal pain

Pathognomonic radiographic sign

"Fetal head in pelvis" appearance

Definitive diagnostic test

Urine microscopy for ova

Potential long-term complication

Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder

Other imaging findings

Fine ureteral calcifications, bladder wall thickening

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy from a rural area presents with suprapubic pain, increased urinary frequency, and occasional hematuria, with no incontinence or systemic symptoms. He appears thin, has normal external genitalia, and has no significant medical history. Imaging shows multiple small, smooth bladder stones. What is the most likely cause?

options.label: A
options.text: Bladder outlet obstruction leading to urinary stasis

options.label: D
options.text: Foreign body presence in the bladder

questions.explanation:
Type

Primary Bladder Stones

Secondary Bladder Stones

Causes

Nutritional deficiency (Vitamins A, B6, magnesium, protein-carbohydrate imbalance) (Option C)

Bladder outlet obstruction, infection, foreign body presence (Option A, B, D)

Common Composition

Ammonium urate, calcium oxalate

Uric acid, struvite (infection-related)

Common Population

Children in developing countries

Adults with urinary tract dysfunction or infection

Clinical Presentation

May be asymptomatic or present with dysuria, hematuria

Hematuria, dysuria, frequency and urgency,

questions.text: Which of the following statements about ectopia vesicae is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: More common in females than males

options.label: C
options.text: Increased risk of urinary bladder adenocarcinoma

options.label: D
options.text: Resolves on its own without surgery

questions.correct_answer: C. Increased risk of urinary bladder adenocarcinoma
questions.explanation:
Clinical Feature

Description

Visible Bladder Exposure

The bladder mucosa is exposed on the lower abdomen, typically above the pubic symphysis, and can range from the exposed trigone to the entire bladder.

Genital Abnormalities

Males: Epispadias (urethra opens on the dorsal side of the penis), short and broad penis, upward curvature

Females: Bifid clitoris, separation of the labia minora, abnormal vaginal opening

Abdominal Wall Defect
  • Absence of lower abdominal wall muscles, widened pubic symphysis, diastasis of rectus muscles
  • Outward rotation of pelvic bones
  • Higher incidence of indirect inguinal hernia

Urological

Continuous leakage of urine due to the inability to close the bladder outlet. Vesicoureteral reflux, possible renal anomalies like renal dysplasia or hydronephrosis. (Option B ruled out)

Anorectum
  • Rectal prolapse
  • Imperforate anus
  • Shortened perineum

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with diabetes and Parkinson’s disease presents with a 6-month history of difficulty urinating, incomplete bladder emptying, and frequent nighttime urination. A post-void residual volume test shows significant urine retention. Which of the following conditions is least likely the primary cause of his chronic urinary retention?
questions.explanation:
Chronic Urinary Retention

Painless inability to fully empty the bladder, leading to elevated post-void residual volume.

Primary Cause

Bladder outlet obstruction (BOO)

Causes and Contributing Factors
  • Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH)
  • Bladder Neck Stenosis
  • Detrusor underactivity
  • Neurological Conditions: Disorders like Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, stroke, and MS affect bladder control.
  • Diabetic neuropathy
  • Medications: Drugs such as anticholinergics and β3-agonists impact bladder muscle function.
  • Urethral Stricture

Complications
  • Hydronephrosis
  • Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs)
  • Bladder Stones
  • Bladder Damage: Persistent overstretching weakens the bladder muscle.
  • Kidney Damage
  • Overflow Incontinence

Treatment
  • Treatment is based on the underlying cause, which may include addressing bladder outlet obstruction, managing detrusor underactivity, and treating other contributing factors.
  • Urgent catheterization is required for patients with chronic retention and renal impairment to facilitate renal function recovery, with the possibility of postobstructive diuresis.

Acute Urinary Retention

Painful, sudden inability to urinate despite a full bladder.

Causes
  • Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH): Leading cause, especially in men with a history of chronic retention.
  • Medications: Drugs like sympathomimetics, anesthetics, and opioids can impair bladder function.
  • Neurological Conditions: acute events like stroke or spinal cord injury
  • Urethral Stricture
  • Blood Clots
  • Fecal Impaction from chronic constipation

Treatment

Catheterization: Immediate bladder drainage for acute retention.

Postobstructive diuresis: Patients may experience a high urine output after catheterization, requiring careful fluid management and electrolyte monitoring
